visuals.title: Parseval's Theorem: Time Domain Power = Frequency Domain Power
visuals.description: The average power of a periodic signal can be computed either by integrating |x(t)|² over one period, or by summing |X_k|² over all harmonics. Both give the same answer.

visuals.title: Power Spectrum |X_k|² of a Square Pulse Train
visuals.description: The power in each harmonic is |X_k|². Most power is concentrated in the low harmonics. Higher harmonics contribute diminishing amounts.

visuals.title: Cumulative Power: How Many Harmonics Capture Most Energy?
visuals.description: As you include more harmonics, the cumulative power approaches the total. For a square wave, ~95% of power is captured within the first 5 harmonics.

visuals.title: Time Domain: |x(t)|² and Its Average
visuals.description: The average of |x(t)|² over one period gives the average power. For a square wave with amplitude A, P_avg = A²·(d/T₀) where d is the pulse width.

visuals.title: Interactive: Verify Parseval's Theorem
visuals.description: Compute power in both domains and verify they match. Add harmonics one by one and watch the frequency-domain sum approach the time-domain integral.

visuals.title: Bandwidth Estimation: 95% Power Bandwidth
visuals.description: The 95% power bandwidth is the range of harmonics that capture 95% of the signal's power. Smoother signals have narrower bandwidth.

visuals.title: RMS Value from Fourier Coefficients
visuals.description: x_rms = √(P_avg) = √(Σ|X_k|²). You can compute RMS directly from the spectrum without ever going to the time domain.

visuals.title: Power Distribution: DC vs 1st vs Higher Harmonics
visuals.description: For a typical signal, the DC term and fundamental harmonic carry most of the power. Higher harmonics contribute diminishing fractions.

visuals.title: Interactive: Compare RMS of Different Waveforms
visuals.description: Switch between square, triangle, and sawtooth waveforms. Compare their RMS values computed from both time and frequency domains.

visuals.title: Waveform View: Signal Reconstructed with Limited Bandwidth
visuals.description: A signal reconstructed with only the first few harmonics vs the full signal. The limited-bandwidth version captures most of the energy but loses sharp features.
